chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: History of palpitations
chapter.summary: Covers the management of people with a history of palpitations.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 16 years onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: When should I refer a person with a history of palpitations?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Following initial assessment:

  • Refer urgently to cardiology if the person has:
    • A history of syncope or near syncope.
    • Palpitations precipitated by exercise.
    • A family history of sudden cardiac death under the age of 40 years.
    • Second degree or third degree atrioventricular block on the 12 lead electrocardiogram (ECG).
  • Refer routinely to cardiology if the person has:
    • Accompanying chest pain or lightheadedness.
    • History or physical symptoms of structural heart disease, heart failure, or hypertension.
    • A resting ECG abnormality, other than second degree or third degree atrioventricular block.
    • A history of recurrent sustained tachyarrhythmia, atrial fibrillation, or flutter.
    • A history of symptoms that are clearly consistent with paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (sudden onset and offset of a fast regular heartbeat, with multiple uneventful ambulatory rhythm monitor recordings).
    • Ventricular extrasystoles (ectopics):
      • If underlying heart disease is suspected from the clinical assessment and/or ECG, or
      • If extrasystoles are frequent or ventricular tachycardia (VT) is suspected.
  • If the person has suspected paroxysmal atrial fibrillation (PAF) — see the CKS topic on Atrial fibrillation for more information on management.
  • Referral is generally not indicated if palpitations are isolated, the 12 lead electrocardiogram is normal, and if symptoms are:
    • Not provoked by exercise.
    • Not associated with lightheadedness, syncope, persistent breathlessness, or chest pain.
    • Not associated with a history or signs of structural heart disease, heart failure, or hypertension.
    • Not associated with a family history of sudden cardiac death.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on referral of people with a history of palpitations are based on expert opinion in the European guideline Management of patients with palpitations: a position paper from the European Heart Rhythm Association [Raviele, 2011], and UK regional clinical guidelines Pathways for Cardiology Symptoms in Primary Care [Benett, 2012] and Guidance on the management of palpitations in primary care [Fay, 2018].

  • Information is also supported by expert opinion in the review articles Diagnostic approach to Palpitations [Abbott, 2005],10 steps before you refer for palpitations [Wolff, 2009b], Outpatient approach to palpitations [Wexler, 2011], and Assessment of palpitations [Gale, 2016].
Urgent or routine referral
  • The information on which signs and symptoms indicate urgent and routine referral is based on expert opinion in the BMJ 'Practice Pointer' Assessment of palpitations [Gale, 2016].
Ventricular extrasystoles (ectopics)
  • The review article Treating patients with ventricular ectopic beats [Ng, 2006] recommends that people with frequent extrasystoles or any suggestion of ventricular tachycardia (VT) should be referred to cardiology.

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I investigate a person with a history of palpitations in primary care?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• For people who do not need to be referred:
    • Arrange blood tests including a full blood count, urea and electrolytes, thyroid function tests, liver function tests, and HbA1c to help identify any underlying cause. If any is/are identified, manage or refer appropriately.
    • Carry out a cardiovascular risk assessment and manage risk factors as appropriate. See the CKS topic on CVD risk assessment and management for further information.
  • If the cause of the palpitations remains unclear:
    • If symptoms are relatively infrequent (less than once a week) and last for an hour or more, advise the person to attend an Accident and Emergency department, or their GP surgery, for an electrocardiogram (ECG) during the next episode. Provide a letter to be given to the healthcare professional requesting an ECG immediately on presentation during an episode.
    • If symptoms are short-lived, arrange ambulatory monitoring in primary care if available, or refer to cardiology. The type of monitoring required is dependent on the frequency and duration of symptoms:
      • If symptoms are short lived but frequent (for example, daily), a 24-hour or 48-hour Holter monitor is appropriate.
      • If symptoms are short lived and infrequent (for example, less than once a week), a self-activated recorder or an event monitor is appropriate.
    • Arrange an echocardiogram if:
      • A murmur is found on examination or if heart failure is suspected. For more information, see the CKS topic on Heart failure - chronic.
      • Structural heart disease is suspected, for example the ECG shows left bundle branch block, left ventricular hypertrophy, or Q-waves.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on investigations for people with a history of palpitations are based on expert opinion in the European guideline Management of patients with palpitations: a position paper from the European Heart Rhythm Association [Raviele, 2011], and UK regional clinical guidelines Pathways for Cardiology Symptoms in Primary Care [Benett, 2012] and Guidance on the management of palpitations in primary care [Fay, 2018]; together with expert opinion in the review articles Diagnostic approach to Palpitations [Abbott, 2005],10 steps before you refer for palpitations [Wolff, 2009b], Outpatient approach to palpitations [Wexler, 2011], and Assessment of palpitations [Gale, 2016].

Additional investigations if the cause of palpitations is unclear
  • The information on different types of ambulatory monitoring are based on the UK regional clinical guideline Pathways for cardiology symptoms in primary care [Benett, 2012], the BMJ Best Practice guideline Evaluation of Palpitations [BMJ Best Practice, 2018], and expert opinion in the review articles 10 steps before you refer for palpitations [Wolff, 2009a], Assessment of palpitations [Gale, 2016], and Investigating palpitations: the role of Holter monitoring and loop recorders [Abi Khalil, 2017].
  • A UK regional clinical guideline recommends that an echocardiogram should be requested if a murmur or structural heart disease is suspected [Benett, 2012].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage a person with a history of palpitations in primary care?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Management should be directed towards treating the underlying cause where possible. For people diagnosed with:
    • Sinus tachycardia — manage the underlying cause and any cardiovascular risk factors identified, and give lifestyle advice.
    • Atrial extrasystoles (ectopics) — manage any cardiovascular risk factors identified and give lifestyle advice.
    • Ventricular extrasystoles (ectopics):
      • Manage any cardiovascular risk factors.
      • If there are no features of underlying heart disease and palpitations are infrequent, reassure and offer lifestyle advice.
  • Arrange referral to cardiology if heart failure or valve disease is confirmed on echocardiogram or where there is uncertainty about the underlying cause, especially where palpitations are recurrent.
  • Give advice about driving and work if appropriate.
    • The Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) regulations state that:
      • For Group 1 entitlement, driving must cease if an arrhythmia has caused or is likely to cause incapacity. Driving may be permitted when the underlying cause has been identified and controlled for at least 4 weeks.
      • For Group 2 entitlement, the driver is disqualified from driving if an arrhythmia has caused or is likely to cause incapacity. Driving may be permitted when the underlying cause has been identified and the arrhythmia is controlled for at least 3 months.
      • See the DVLA guide Assessing fitness to drive – a guide for medical professionals for further information.
    • People with certain occupations, for example those working at height or with potentially dangerous machinery, will need to stop work until a diagnosis is confirmed or the underlying condition is treated.
  • Offer general information and advice about palpitations. Patient leaflets are available from the NHS, Patient.info, and the British Heart Foundation.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on management of people with a history of palpitations are based on expert opinion in the European guideline Management of patients with palpitations: a position paper from the European Heart Rhythm Association [Raviele, 2011], and UK regional clinical guidelines Pathways for cardiology symptoms in primary care [Benett, 2012] and Guidance on the management of palpitations in primary care [Fay, 2010]; together with expert opinion in the review articles Diagnostic approach to palpitations [Abbott, 2005], Treating patients with ventricular ectopic beats [Ng, 2006], 10 steps before you refer for palpitations [Wolff, 2009a], and Outpatient approach to palpitations [Wexler, 2011].

Ventricular extrasystoles (ectopics)
  • The review article Treating patients with ventricular ectopic beats [Ng, 2006] recommends that in the absence of any heart disease or suspicion of ventricular tachycardia and where ventricular extrasystoles are infrequent, reassurance is appropriate along with lifestyle advice and cardiovascular risk assessment.
Advice about work
  • The recommendations on avoiding occupational situations where symptoms and complications of palpitations have potential to cause harm to the person or others is based on expert opinion in the review article 10 steps before you refer for palpitations [Wolff, 2009a].
